misconceptions.name: Implemented an entirely different problem (distance between points instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points rather than a program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and prints the corresponding letter grade using conditional ranges. There is no handling of a single grade input or mapping to letter grades, so the submission does not address the specified requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads coordinates for two points and computes the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read one numeric grade between 0 and 100 and use conditional statements to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the given ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade value.
Program computes a distance formula using Math.sqrt and Math.pow instead of using conditional logic for grade ranges.
No conditional checks for grade intervals (90-100, 80-89, etc.).
Output describes distance between points, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions or reuse of code from a distance-calculation exercise, leading to misinterpretation of the current problem requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the problem statement and focus on its exact requirements: read one numeric grade, then use if/else-if/else (or equivalent) to check which range the grade falls into and print the correct letter grade. Avoid reusing code from unrelated problems unless you first verify that it matches the current specification.
related_concepts: Input/output design based on a specification
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is devoted to computing distance between two points, with no elements related to grade input or letter-grade mapping. This strongly indicates the student implemented the wrong problem.

evidence.note: This code reads four doubles (x1, y1, x2, y2) and computes a geometric distance, with no handling of a single numeric grade or any letter-grade logic as required by the assignment.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that solves a completely different problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the required 'Grade Calculator' problem. The submission lacks any code related to reading a single numeric grade, implementing conditional logic for grading, or outputting a letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted the solution for a previous or different task, believing it fulfilled the requirements of Q3: Grade Calculator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task Q3 requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional statements (if/else if/else) to print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Program attempts to read four variables (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade.
Output is the distance formula result, not a letter grade.
Missing all conditional (if/else if) logic required for grading.
misconceptions.root_cause: Incorrect file submission or severe misreading of the assignment prompt for Q3.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the instructions for Q3 carefully and implement the required logic (input, if-else structure, and corresponding output) for a grade calculator.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code text clearly implements the distance formula and prompts for four coordinates, which has zero correspondence with the Grade Calculator problem statement.

evidence.note: The entire program implements the distance formula, not the grade calculator logic required for Q3.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Solved
misconceptions.description: The student has completely misunderstood the assignment and solved a different problem (distance between two points) instead of the grade calculator that was requested.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a distance calculation problem, possibly confusing this assignment with a different one or not reading the requirements carefully.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment Q3 requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade. The student should read one integer/double input, not four inputs for coordinates.
symptoms: Program reads four coordinate inputs instead of one grade
Program calculates distance between two points instead of determining letter grade
Output format is completely different from expected ('The distance of the two points is' instead of 'Letter grade:')
No conditional logic for grade ranges
misconceptions.root_cause: Fundamental misreading or misunderstanding of the assignment requirements. The student either read the wrong problem, confused this with another assignment, or did not carefully review the problem statement before coding.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the assignment Q3 carefully. The task is to read ONE grade value (0-100) and use if-else statements to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code solves an entirely different problem with different inputs, different logic, and different output. This is unambiguously the wrong assignment.

evidence.note: Reads four coordinate values instead of one grade value (0-100)

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %s%n", Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));
evidence.note: Calculates Euclidean distance formula instead of implementing grade range logic

misconceptions.name: Implemented the wrong problem (distance formula instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the distance between two points instead of a grade calculator that reads a numeric grade (0-100) and outputs a letter grade (A-F) based on specified ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: I need to write a program that reads coordinates for two points and prints the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 and then use conditional statements to map that numeric grade to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the given ranges, and print the letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single numeric grade.
No conditional logic to map numeric ranges to letter grades.
Output describes the distance between two points, not a letter grade.
Completely different formula (distance formula) from the required grade classification logic.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the problem requirements, likely confusing this question with a different assignment (distance between two points).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the question carefully and identify the required inputs (a single numeric grade) and outputs (a letter grade). Then design a program that reads one number, uses if/else-if conditions to check which range it falls into (90–100, 80–89, etc.), and prints the corresponding letter grade.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric ranges to categories using conditionals
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure, prompts, inputs, and output of the program correspond to a standard distance-between-points problem and do not include any elements of a grade calculator.

evidence.note: All input is for coordinate pairs and the output is a distance calculation; there is no reading of a numeric grade or mapping to a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Complete disregard for assignment requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a completely different problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the required Grade Calculator problem. This indicates a fundamental misunderstanding or misinterpretation of the task requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that the submitted code, which solves a problem about calculating distance between points, fulfills the requirement to build a Grade Calculator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must address the specified rubric and goal, which requires reading a single numeric grade and outputting a letter grade based on conditional ranges (if/else structure).
symptoms: Code reads four inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one numeric grade.
Code calculates a distance using the distance formula instead of performing grade comparison logic.
Class name ('DistanceBetweenPoints') reflects the wrong task.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misreading or confusing the required problem (Q3 Grade Calculator) with a solution developed for a different, likely previous, problem (Distance Between Points).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment document carefully and write a new program that specifically solves the Grade Calculator task, reading a single input and using if/else logic for grading.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence. The student submitted entirely irrelevant code (Distance Between Points calculation) for the required task (Grade Calculator).

evidence.note: The entire code implements the distance formula and reads four points, instead of implementing a Grade Calculator which would read one grade and use conditional logic.

misconceptions.name: Complete misinterpretation of assignment requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a solution for calculating the distance between two points in a coordinate system, rather than a grade calculator that evaluates numeric grades and outputs letter grades.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment was asking them to calculate the Euclidean distance between two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment asks for a program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on specified ranges: A (90-100), B (80-89), C (70-79), D (60-69), F (<60).
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates instead of a grade
No conditional logic for grade ranges
No letter grade output
No grade comparison (90-100, 80-89, etc.)
Math formula is for distance, not grading
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either read the wrong assignment or completely misunderstood the problem requirements. Possible causes: Wrong problem number copied, failed to read Q3 carefully, or copied code from a different assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read Q3 carefully. The task is to: (1) Read ONE numeric grade, (2) Use if-else statements to check grade ranges, (3) Output the appropriate letter grade. Start fresh with a simple if-else chain for the five grade bands.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: This is unambiguous—the submitted code solves a completely different problem. The code calculates distance using the distance formula √((x2-x1)² + (y2-y1)²), while the assignment explicitly requires grade range evaluation and letter output.

evidence.note: Prompts for coordinate points (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade value.

evidence.snippet: System.out.printf("The distance of the two points is %s%n", Math.sqrt(Math.pow(x2 - x1, 2) + Math.pow(y2 - y1, 2)));
evidence.note: Calculates Euclidean distance using distance formula. This is the opposite of what Q3 requires—no grade ranges, no letter output.
